response.answer_text: There are many good answers posted, and I can’t really top them. I will add a few of my own observations. I’m surprised how many people today are willing to accept the Warren Report’s conclusion that Oswald acted as a lone wolf. That is still perhaps the majority opinion. However, if Oswald was the lone assassin, who would possibly have wanted his story suppressed? No one actually, not Jack Ruby, not LBJ, J Edgar Hoover, the CIA, the Mafia, or anybody. The fact that Oswald was "rubbed out" by a mob goon (Ruby) suggests there were one or more people who didn't want Oswald to "sing." The two bullets to JFK's neck and head suggest a highly skilled shooter or shooters who made their target, not a rookie who missed. Imagine for a moment the envy and revulsion you would feel if you spent several decades in politics, starting at the bottom and working your way to become perhaps the best around when it came to pure politicking and consensus building, and you had ambitions to become president. Then right about the time of your ideal moment to run for the office, along comes a young glamor boy, son of a wealthy magnate, who hadn’t paid nearly the price you did to get where he was, and this young playboy steals your limelight, and to add insult to injury, names you as his running mate mostly because you represent a voting block very different from his, without which he could not possibly win the race, — understand all this and you begin to see the very toxic dynamic between LBJ and JFK. No doubt, Johnson felt excluded from JFK’s inner circle and very resentful. I’m pretty sure LBJ was not receiving the daily presidential briefings, which all VPs receive nowadays. The book that opened my eyes to this dark picture of LBJ is Blood, Money and Power by Barr McClellan, a former government lawyer with inside knowledge. LBJ very much had the means, motive, and opportunity to engineer a plot that to this day remains hidden, except we do know about the conspiracy to suppress evidence conducted mostly by our government, which could be attributed to many causes. (Fear of an uprising, instability, threats to powerful people, JFK’s desire to reduce tax loopholes for the oil industry, etc.) Don't forget, LBJ and Hoover were neighbors, both strongmen with their own agendas who must have enjoyed private conversations. LBJ had the motive: to kill JFK to “save the country,” and he might have easily arm-twisted Hoover into concealing evidence and lines of inquiry, possibly by threat of blackmail. Let’s face it: dastardly deeds have been committed all throughout history. Why would American history be any different? Today, the Deep State is alive and well, virtually beyond the reach of elected officials. What happened to JFK could happen again. The Hillary Clinton / Russian email skullduggery going on today is quite possibly evidence of the Deep State(s) at work. Let’s hope our government and all its nooks and crannies acts responsibly and for the greater good of the people, rather than personal and private agendas. And let’s hope continued scholarship in the JFK assassination one day reveals the plot in full. Postscript: I recently finished Mary’s Mosaic by Peter Janey and it changed my thinking. As the son of a high-ranking CIA officer, and family friend of Mary Pinchot Meyer, the subject of the book, Janey is intimately connected to his subject, which is the murder of Mary Meyer (JFK’s primary mistress), and how it relates to the murder of JFK. While Janey believes Johnson was an active player in JFK’s assassination, he claims it was the CIA’s James Jesus Angleton who architected if not the coup itself, at least the coverup of the CIA’s involvement. (Rogue elements of the CIA were involved, including perhaps Bill Harvey who hated JFK, according to Jefferson Morley’s “The Ghost.”) I highly recommend Mary’s Mosaic, which is oddly more or less blacklisted from almost all media, yet it’s not doing badly, already in its 3rd printing. Janey draws on many researchers, all of whom fill in bits of the puzzle to form a relatively clear outline of the Kennedy assassination, in which the CIA is central to the plot. The book also reveals new and shocking information on the close working relationship between CIA and the mainstream American press, which cooperated with CIA on spinning a great many stories, including JFK’s assassination and the overthrow of many Communist dictatorships around the world in which the CIA was actively involved. According to Janey, JFK was killed mostly because of his vigorous pursuit of peaceful detente with the Soviets (particularly Khrushchev), his failure to deal aggressively with Cuba, his plans to scale down in Viet Nam, and his general optimism in mankind’s ability to live in peaceful harmony, which conflicted with the agendas of the 3-letter agencies, which required perpetual conflict to justify their existence. This is of course consistent with Eisenhower’s warning to beware of the military industrial complex and its expanding influence in American society.
